author: By Brett Berk
title: Selling Cars, Plus Coffee, Tea or a Fancy Dinner
description: Automakers are building “brand experience centers” to pitch their vehicles to consumers without the hard sell of a showroom.
content: Out: simple auto showrooms. In: the “brand experience center.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Peck
title: What Do You Think You Should Be Paid?
description: It’s now a common job interview question. It can also be a trap. Here’s how to answer.
content: When she started her career in tech more than a decade ago, Shanae Chapman soon grew comfortable answering traditional interview questions: greatest strengths (time management, attention to detail), weaknesses (prioritization). “Tell me about yourself” was kind of tricky, at first. No one in her family had ever held a corporate job before, and the question is actually weird. What exactly did the interviewer want to know? She figured it out quickly enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Will Omicron Meet Its Match in the Perseverance of New Yorkers?
description: A new variant is surging, but vaccination rates are high, face masks are ubiquitous and residents are finding ways to soldier on.
content: On various occasions during the fall, I tried and failed to make a dinner reservation at Gage & Tollner, the historic restaurant on the Fulton Mall in Brooklyn that reopened during the spring to much fanfare, after 17 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austan Goolsbee
title: The Missing Data in the Inflation Debate
description: Until we know how price spikes affect the poor, we won’t see their real impact.
content: With inflation growing at its fastest rate in decades, economists are locked in a debate over whether it stems from too much stimulus or from temporary, pandemic-induced supply-chain pressures. Less discussed are the ways that the pain of inflation may not be shared equally.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kathryn Schulz Doesn’t Count Any Reading Pleasures as Guilty
description: “I adore William James and Henry James, but did I also read E.L. James back in 2011? You bet.”
content: “I adore William James and Henry James,” says the author Kathryn Schulz, whose latest book is the memoir “Lost & Found” — “but did I also read E. L. James back in 2011? You bet.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Biden and Putin Will Hold a Call on Ukraine
description: The Russian president requested Thursday’s call, which will be the second time in three weeks that the two leaders speak about tensions at the Ukrainian border.
content: President Biden will talk to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Thursday afternoon about the grinding crisis at the Ukrainian border, White House officials said, the second time in a little over three weeks that the two leaders will speak directly about what Washington sees as Moscow’s effort to redraw the map of Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan DiTrolio
title: Is There Such a Thing as a Slow News Week?
description: The answer is yes. And Times editors are always preparing for it.
content: Ask any journalist: The news cycle is relentless, exhausting, ever-churning and wildly unpredictable. A bill gets caught up in the House; a world leader makes a blunder; a new variant of coronavirus grips the nation. In a normal week, any of those stories and more may battle for front-page treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: I Grew Up Celebrating New Year’s Eve Like Frederick Douglass
description: Watch Night began as a vigil commemorating the Emancipation Proclamation and has become a way to honor the past and look to the future.
content: The last place that I wanted to be on Dec. 31 was church. But there I was on New Year’s Eve, clustered next to a host of other Black teenagers in the back of the sanctuary for our Watch Night service. We were waiting to be freed to go to the clubs and house parties that had begun their festivities without us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryant Rousseau
title: In 2021, We Were There: The Year’s 14 Most Popular Dispatches
description: Not even a pandemic, wars or autocrats could prevent our correspondents from seeking out secrets and surprises to share with readers. They sent dispatches from 40 countries on six continents.
content: As the world reopened cautiously in 2021, our correspondents seized the chance to venture out in search of stories that would astonish, delight, provoke and enlighten. We went from the heights of a Himalayan ski slope to the ocean depths off the Philippines where amiable giants dive, and from a rugged island where a whistling language is still used to an Italian atelier where robots carve the sculptures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.K., With Surging Cases, Is on ‘War Footing’ Against Virus
description: With cases surging and straining health care and other services, Britain’s challenges foreshadow the impact of the Omicron variant in other countries.
content: England’s National Health Service “is now on a war footing,” one of its top medical officials warned on Thursday, saying its hospitals would erect field wards to help deal with the surge in coronavirus cases that has produced a steep rise in hospitalizations nationally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: More Millennials Are Renting Because They Have To
description: A competitive housing market has fueled a surge in rental applications by the generation, especially in smaller cities.
content: As more millennials seek to become first-time home buyers in this immensely competitive pandemic market, many are finding that renting is the only option — even though they have the income and down payment required to make a purchase. A recent study by RentCafe found that high-earning millennials (with an annual income of more than $50,000) submitted 39 percent of all rental apartment applications in 2021, their largest share in five years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Everybody Into the Metaverse! Virtual Reality Beckons Big Tech.
description: Tech’s biggest companies are joining game makers and start-ups in pursuit of an immersive digital world that some have been working on for years.
content: The metaverse, one of the most buzzy terms of the tech industry, could be many things. It could be a virtual world where imagination is the only limit. Or it could be a less fantastical place for holding business meetings without leaving home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Tiger Bites Arm of Man Reaching Into Enclosure at Florida Zoo, Officials Say
description: The man, who worked for a cleaning service, had entered a restricted area at the Naples Zoo, the authorities said. The tiger was shot and killed.
content: A man who worked for a cleaning service at the Naples Zoo in Florida was seriously injured on Wednesday when a tiger bit his arm after he went into a restricted area and reached into the animal’s enclosure, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharif Hassan
title: Former Afghan President Says He Fled Nation to ‘Save Kabul’
description: In his first interview since escaping Afghanistan as the Taliban advanced on the capital, Ashraf Ghani defended himself against charges that he abandoned his country in its hour of need.
content: Former President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan said he fled the country to prevent the destruction of Kabul as Taliban fighters advanced on the capital, offering the most detailed defense of his actions since the government’s collapse in August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: Mexico says it will allow cruise ships with Covid outbreaks to dock.
description: The Latin American nation is among the few in the world to have imposed no restrictions or testing requirements for travelers.
content: MEXICO CITY — Mexico’s government announced this week that it would let cruise ships dock at its ports, even if passengers have tested positive for the coronavirus, and also allow asymptomatic travelers to disembark on its shores.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
title: China, holding to its ‘zero Covid’ strategy, keeps a city of 13 million locked down.
description: The severe measures in Xi’an have prompted concern, as residents complain on social media of having trouble ordering food online.
content: China, racing to control one of its worst outbreaks in a single city since the beginning of the pandemic, has put in place a sweeping lockdown and mass testing drives, making clear that the country has no intention of abandoning its “zero Covid” policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker, Steve Eder and David D. Kirkpatrick
title: After 4 Killings, ‘Officer of the Year’ Is Still on the Job
description: A Pennsylvania state trooper was returned to duty following three investigations by his own agency. A fourth inquiry is underway.
content: LEBANON, Pa. — In November 2008, Pennsylvania Trooper Jay Splain was honored at a county law enforcement banquet as a hero, the police officer of the year. The reason: He had shot and killed a suicidal man who allegedly pointed an Uzi submachine gun at him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: The Stories That Defined California in 2021
description: Here’s what we learned about the Golden State this strange year.
content: Looking back on this year as we head into the new one, it may feel as if not much changed in California during 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: As At-Home Tests Surge, Doubts Rise About Accuracy of Public Covid Counts
description: Most of the results of rapid tests are not reported. That’s magnifying questions about how best to measure the spread of the virus.
content: Millions of rapid at-home Covid tests are flying off pharmacy shelves across the country, giving Americans an instant, if sometimes imperfect, read on whether they are infected with the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo and Anne Mancuso
title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Warren, N.J.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: New in Paperback: ‘Of Women and Salt’ and ‘Drug Use for Grown-Ups’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: AGELESS: The New Science of Getting Older Without Getting Old, by Andrew Steele. (Anchor, 352 pp., $17.) A biologist and physicist describes how our bodily systems decline over time and examines the emerging therapies attempting to slow that process. “Our ultimate aspiration, Steele makes clear, should not be simply improving people’s quality of life as they age,” our reviewer, Annie Murphy Paul, noted. “It should be radically extending the human life span.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: I Lied to My Parents. How Do I Get Them to Believe the Truth Now?
description: A reader seeks advice on correcting a false statement made in a moment of passion.
content: Five years ago, when I was still in college, my parents and I agreed not to discuss politics. They have become extremely conservative, which leads to conflict between us. We have mostly lived up to this pact. But this week, during my holiday visit home, they have been out of control. Every day, they make some remark about “the libs,” gun control (even though none of us owns guns) or reproductive rights. I’ve mostly ignored them. But finally, after an ill-informed comment about abortion, I’d had it: I told them at dinner I went on birth control pills when I was 15 — which isn’t true. I don’t know why I said it. Now they’re upset about something that didn’t happen 10 years ago, and they won’t believe the truth. Help!
source.name: The New York Times

title: Can a Tiny Territory in the South Pacific Power Tesla’s Ambitions?
description: Nickel is vital to electric car batteries, but extracting it is dirty and destructive. A plant with a turbulent history in New Caledonia is about to become an experiment in doing it better.
content: GORO, New Caledonia — From the reef-fringed coast of New Caledonia, the Coral Sea stretches into the South Pacific. Slender native pines, listing like whimsical Christmas trees, punctuate the shoreline. The landscape, one of the most biodiverse on the planet, is astonishingly beautiful until the crest of a hill where a different vista unfolds: a gouged red earth pierced by belching smokestacks and giant trucks rumbling across the lunar-like terrain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Noah Weiland
title: As Omicron Spreads, Officials Ponder What It Means to Be ‘Fully Vaccinated’
description: The contagious new variant has companies and government officials wondering whether Americans can really be considered vaccinated without booster shots.
content: Goldman Sachs and Jefferies, the investment banks, are demanding that employees get booster shots. The University of Oregon and other institutions are requiring that students and staff members get boosters. New York State has said it plans to stop considering residents fully vaccinated unless they’ve gotten the shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Covid is Surging and Disrupting Life Across the City Again
description: Libraries are closing, urgent care centers are running out of healthy staff members and subway lines have been suspended as the state is setting new case records.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday, and the year is almost coming to a close. Today we’ll look at how the new Omicron-fueled surge in coronavirus infections is prompting shutdowns and disrupting life across the city. We’ll also look at the uncertain fate of the Sandy Ground neighborhood in Staten Island, the oldest continuously inhabited free Black settlement in the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Trump’s Social Media Return — and What Else to Expect in 2022
description: But don’t expect Congress to get its act together on tech legislation.
content: I know, I know: “Not another prediction list …” But stick with me. After all, my first forecast from last year came true — although the Capitol siege moved the timetable forward considerably.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Trachta
title: ‘And Just Like That’ Episode 5 Recap: Painfully Hip
description: This week’s episode was in many ways a reminder of what drew so many fans to the franchise in the first place.
content: For a show with such a sultry title, the love scenes in the original “Sex and the City” were usually more comedic than hot. At various points, Carrie sleeps with a guy who performs like a “jack rabbit,” Charlotte dates a man who blacks out and screams obscenities in bed, Miranda deals with an “overeater,” and Samantha takes a literal roll in the hay with a farmer, just to name a few of the many silly sexual encounters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Going Out and Worried About Covid Safety? There’s a Calculator for That.
description: Age + vaccination status + number of guests + ZIP code + activity = Should I even leave the house?
content: Before David Lee gathered with his parents for Christmas, he and his family took Covid-19 precautions. They isolated themselves a few days before meeting. His parents, who are more vulnerable because of their age, got the vaccine booster shot, as did Mr. Lee, 43, a photo editor who lives in Toronto. His children, ages 8 and 10, got their first vaccine shot. And they all took rapid tests leading up to the holiday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: The Best Seller List Has a Century Club with Limited Membership
description: What books sell briskly for more than 100 weeks? There’s no formula, but pictures help.
content: LONG HAULERS On Nov. 4, 2014 — years before the pandemic, before people the world over had memorized the Greek alphabet as if by osmosis — Rupi Kaur published her debut poetry collection, “Milk and Honey.” The book is now in its 190th week on the paperback trade fiction list, one of fewer than a dozen nonseries titles that have been best sellers for more than 100 weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘The Lost Daughter’ Review: The Parent Trap
description: This dreamy thriller follows an academic with a mysterious past who heads to a beach vacation on the Greek islands.
content: Draped in a pall of melancholy that more than fulfills the promise of its title, “The Lost Daughter” — Maggie Gyllenhaal’s seductive first feature as director — is a movie filled with portents. These start to surface almost immediately as Leda (Olivia Colman), a gifted professor of comparative literature, begins a Greek island vacation, laden with books and scholarly intentions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Sam Fender, a Songwriter Caught Between Stardom and His Hometown
description: The musician is fast becoming one of Britain’s biggest rock acts with tracks about working class life in North Shields. Can he let himself leave the town?
content: NORTH SHIELDS, England — Sam Fender, a singer-songwriter often labeled Britain’s answer to Bruce Springsteen, realized his life had changed for good on Halloween.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan, Giulia Heyward and Christine Chung
title: Officer Whose Bullet Killed a 14-Year-Old Girl Wanted to ‘Change’ the Police
description: As an L.A.P.D. officer, William Jones Jr. said he wanted the public “not to be scared of us.” He is now under investigation for a shooting that killed Valentina Orellana Peralta and an unarmed assault suspect.
content: LOS ANGELES — When he first moved to Los Angeles 15 years ago, William Dorsey Jones Jr. was like many others before him, hoping to find a career in the entertainment industry. He went so far as to start his own company, Entourage Entertainment Group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey
title: A World Divided by Covid and Other Ills United to Explore Space
description: “I’ve always seen space as an area where we cooperate, through all the trying times,” said a professor who oversaw mission control for the global effort to launch a $10 billion telescope into space.
content: America was a nation divided, but that did not stop it from building parts of the James Webb Space Telescope in a red state and testing them in a blue one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: BBC Will Look Into Alan Dershowitz Appearance on Maxwell Segment
description: The American lawyer spoke to the British broadcaster about the verdict in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, but his connections to the case were not made clear.
content: On Wednesday evening, BBC viewers heard from the American lawyer Alan M. Dershowitz about the guilty verdict in the case of Ghislaine Maxwell, who was convicted that day of helping the billionaire Jeffrey Epstein recruit, groom and sexually abuse underage girls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh
title: India reckons with the possibility of a third wave of the virus.
description: The health ministry recorded more than 13,000 new cases in a day, one of the highest daily totals since October.
content: Health experts in India expressed alarm on Thursday as the country recorded a coronavirus surge, probably fueled by the Omicron variant, that has seen new reported cases more than double in the last four days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arthur Lubow
title: When a Master Printer Picks Up the Camera
description: The first major museum show of Richard Benson’s photographs reveals his inventive use of the medium.
content: PHILADELPHIA — Is technical wizardry enough to make someone an artist?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Novitzky
title: I Investigated Bonds and Clemens. Yes, They Belong in Cooperstown.
description: They deserve Hall of Fame recognition, even though they played in the “steroids era.”
content: Friday is the last day for voters in the Baseball Writers’ Association of America to submit their 2022 Baseball Hall of Fame ballots. Listed on those ballots are two players in their 10th and final year of Hall of Fame eligibility who truly dominated their era but haven’t been voted in: Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: For this New Year’s weekend, our TV critic recommends the new seasons of “Queer Eye” and “Cobra Kai” or a political thriller for fans of “Homeland.”
content: ‘The Accidental Wolf’
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Classical Music Albums to Hear Right Now
description: Music by Liza Lim and Pamela Z, albums of Vivaldi and Walter Piston and work from a classic conductor are some recent recording highlights.
content: Over the last decade, the reputation of the Australian composer Liza Lim has grown steadily, with consistently strong chamber and orchestral albums released on top-flight experimental music labels like Wergo and Kairos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Ukrainians Set Sights on the New Year, Not a New War
description: As the government designates bomb shelters and provides guidance on how to tape windows in case of an attack by Russia, Ukrainians carry on.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — To gauge the mood in Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, as Russia has massed tens of thousands of troops near the border and raised the specter of an invasion, look no further than the Dilettante coffee shop.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Our Favorite Food Stories of 2021
description: In this special edition of the T List, scorched rice, messy cakes, fluffy challah — and more.
content: Twenty twenty-one was the year we cautiously returned to dining at our favorite restaurants and hosting loved ones at our own tables. For those not still recovering from numerous failed focaccia attempts, it was also a chance to try new recipes — we’re fond of Roxane Gay’s take on a basil-y chicken Milanese, and Batsheva Hay’s indulgently eggy challah, both of which are highlighted below. That’s because this week, we’re using the T List to look back on our most mouthwatering food stories published in T this year, including those on the bakers creating gloriously disheveled cakes, the specialty food shop where New Yorkers stock up on spices and the rich, crispy gold mine that can be found at the bottom of a pot of rice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: N.F.L. Week 17 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
description: Teams get two tools to deal with the coronavirus surge: shorter quarantines for players who test positive and no Thursday night games.
content: With the league barreling toward the end of the regular season and facing a coronavirus surge that included 90 players testing positive on Monday, the N.F.L. on Tuesday halved the number of days players who test positive have to quarantine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William McDonald
title: Deaths in 2021: Headline Names Against the Backdrop of Pandemic
description: Aaron, Sondheim, Dole and Didion. But the loss of Colin Powell from the virus spoke most directly to the moment the world is in.
content: Hank Aaron was gone. So were Stephen Sondheim, and Bob Dole, and Cicely Tyson, and Larry King, and Joan Didion. Prince Philip, two months short of 100, was buried with all the royal pomp one would expect. But in a year that saw the deaths of a host of figures who helped shape our era in decades past, none spoke more to the still-perilous present moment than that of Colin Powell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilana Kaplan
title: ‘Cheer’ is Back. Coach Monica is Ready.
description: The documentary series on the Navarro College cheerleading team returns to Netflix on Jan. 12.
content: CORSICANA, Texas — Monica Aldama grasped a mike like a pageant queen. The head coach of Navarro College Cheer, who is known for her role on the Netflix documentary series “Cheer,” was hyping up her squad with “mat talk” before bodies began soaring through the air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Everything One Needs
description: John Ewbank’s puzzle is a little risqué.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — With John Ewbank’s debut today, we have reached our 92nd new constructor of the year, bringing the portion of puzzles by new constructors above 25 percent for 2021. This is an incredible feat — congratulations to all 92 constructors who achieved debuts this year. But today is Mr. Ewbank’s day! Let’s celebrate this (rather cheeky) offering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Orah Mark
title: The Storybook Marriage of Alice and Martin Provensen
description: The Provensens lived inside a picture book as much as picture books lived inside them.
content: THE ART OF ALICE & MARTIN PROVENSEN
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz
title: A New Ban on Surprise Medical Bills Starts This Week
description: If you have a medical emergency, you will no longer need to worry about a large bill from a doctor you did not choose.
content: For years, millions of Americans with medical emergencies could receive another nasty surprise: a bill from a doctor they did not choose and who did not accept their insurance. A law that goes into effect Saturday will make many such bills illegal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Todd Gregory, Ceylan Yeginsu and Oscar Lopez
title: The C.D.C. tells travelers to avoid cruises, regardless of vaccination.
description: The move came as the number of outbreaks on ships has grown in recent weeks.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Thursday raised its Covid-19 warning level for cruise ships to 4, the highest, and issued a blunt warning: “Avoid cruise travel regardless of vaccination status.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stella Tan, Rachel Quester, Alexandra Leigh Young, Diana Nguyen, Anita Badejo, Lisa Chow, Dave Shaw, Elisheba Ittoop, Dan Powell, Brad Fisher and Marion Lozano
title: A Nursing Home’s First Day Out of Lockdown: An Update
description: Residents in West Virginia shared their feelings about being allowed to mix again after months of isolation.
content: This week, The Daily is revisiting some of our favorite episodes of the year and checking in on what has happened in the time since they first ran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Friday Briefing: Biden and Putin discuss Ukraine
description: Putin requested the call amid tensions on Ukrainian border.
content: President Joe Biden and Vladimir Putin, the Russian leader, held an important phone call on Thursday, speaking for the second time in less than a month about the crisis at the Ukrainian border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac and Kashmir Hill
title: Are Apple AirTags Being Used to Track People and Steal Cars?
description: Privacy groups sounded alarms about the coin-sized location-tracking devices when they were introduced. Now people are concerned those fears are being realized.
content: On a Sunday night in September, Ashley Estrada was at a friend’s home in Los Angeles when she received a strange notification on her iPhone: “AirTag Detected Near You.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir, Jan Hoffman and Lola Fadulu
title: Pharmaceutical Company Is Found Liable in Landmark Opioid Trial
description: The case was the first of its kind, targeting every point of the prescription opioid supply chain, from manufacturers to pharmacy chains that filled prescriptions.
content: A jury on Thursday found that an opioid manufacturer and distributor contributed to the deadly opioid crisis in New York, inundating the state with prescription painkillers that led to thousands of deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Poupelle of Chimney Town’ Review: Seeking Refuse
description: In this anime feature, a lonely boy strikes up a friendship with a trash creature and searches for stars in a polluted sky.
content: The anime feature “Poupelle of Chimney Town,” the first directorial film from Yusuke Hirota, takes place in a metropolis where the sky is always dark from smoke. The residents are policed by cloaked officials called inquisitors, who make it their business to suppress dissenters, particularly civilians who propose that there might be a world beyond the nearby ocean or the blotted-out firmament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Karasik
title: The Books We Loved as Children Can Comfort Us at the End
description: The cartoonist Paul Karasik spent time with his 103-year-old mother, reading the classics, like E.B. White’s “Charlotte's Web.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: This week’s homes are in Lenox Hill, Chelsea and Flatbush.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller and Andrew Jacobs
title: Covid vaccines rarely lead to problems in younger children, according to two C.D.C. reports.
description: The reports, both released on Thursday, underscored the importance of vaccinating children against the coronavirus.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released two studies on Thursday that underscored the importance of vaccinating children against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David S. Cohen, Greer Donley and Rachel Rebouché
title: Joe Biden Can’t Save Roe v. Wade Alone. But He Can Do This.
description: It’s time to think creatively.
content: The constitutional right to abortion has never been more fragile than it is heading into 2022. The Supreme Court has allowed S.B. 8, Texas’ drastic — and clearly unconstitutional — ban on abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy, to remain in place for months, making Roe v. Wade virtually a dead letter in the state. Even worse, a Supreme Court decision that’s expected this summer is likely to either gut Roe or overturn the precedent altogether, paving the way for total abortion bans in about half the states around the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Muktita Suhartono
title: Indonesia Lets Stranded Refugee Boat Land After Vowing to Turn It Away
description: The boat came shore on Friday with more than 100 Rohingya refugees on board. Indonesia relented under pressure from rights groups.
content: A leaking boat packed with more than 100 Rohingya refugees was towed ashore in Indonesia on Friday, days after the government reversed an earlier decision to turn the stranded vessel away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Greenhouse
title: Do We Have the Supreme Court We Deserve?
description: It has become a willing  participant in a war for the soul of the country.
content: When I left the daily Supreme Court beat back in 2008, the Week in Review, as The Times’s Sunday Review section was then called, invited me to offer some reflections on nearly 30 years of writing about the court, its cases and its members. The long essay ran under the headline “2,691 Decisions,” a number based on an editor’s calculation of how many decisions the court had issued during my time on the beat. I ended it with an observation about the “vital dialogue” between the court and the country. This was my conclusion:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Pentagon Building New Secret Courtroom at Guantánamo Bay
description: The concept is to permit two military judges to hold proceedings simultaneously starting in mid-2023.
content: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon is building a second courtroom for war crimes trials at Guantánamo Bay that will exclude the public from the chamber, the latest move toward secrecy in the nearly 20-year-old detention operation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Crisp-Edged Tofu Straight From Your Oven
description: A coating of cornstarch and oil plus a long stint in a hot oven mimics the deep fryer for this tofu sheet-pan dinner.
content: I used to be convinced that the only way to get truly crisp tofu was to fry it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Bonisteel
title: The Most-Read Food Stories of 2021
description: In the second pandemic year, readers flocked to articles that elevated their cooking skills — and others that simply delighted or disturbed.
content: And so closes the second year of the pandemic, 12 months more of worry, of working from home, of trying to make each meal feel like something new. The articles that readers of the Food section and New York Times Cooking craved this year acknowledged this new reality. Many of our most-read stories offered tips for making weeknight meals faster and more delicious. Some fed readers’ curiosity about a return to dining out, and others delved into disturbing territory: a Southern farmer’s discovery that her ancestors had enslaved people, and revelations about sexual harassment and other abuses at a destination restaurant in Washington State.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Tesla Recalls Some Sedans Over Two Safety Defects
description: The recalls, which Tesla initiated on Dec. 21, affect about 350,000 Model 3s and 120,000 Model S cars.
content: Tesla has told federal regulators that it plans to recall more than 475,000 cars for two separate defects that could affect safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Sharon LaFraniere
title: F.D.A. Plans to Allow 12- to 15-Year-Olds to Receive Pfizer Boosters
description: Regulators are also expected to allow even younger children with immune deficiencies to get an extra shot.
content: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration is planning to broaden eligibility for coronavirus vaccine booster shots on Monday, allowing 12- to 15-year-olds to receive third doses of Pfizer-BioNTech’s vaccine, according to people familiar with the agency’s deliberations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Travel Delays Are Expected After Record Snow Tapers in Western U.S.
description: Though the worst of the week’s winter storms appears to be over, travel delays and extreme cold are expected to continue.
content: The worst of a winter storm that brought record-setting snowfall and low temperatures to portions of the Western United States this week appears to be over, but travel delays, frigid temperatures and lighter snowfall are still expected in the coming days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Fuhrer
title: Harnessing an Unusual Kind of Natural Energy: Dancers’ Body Heat
description: The power of dance? It’s literal at a Glasgow arts center that is installing a geothermal heating and cooling system that runs on heat from dancing bodies.
content: In the pre-vaccine pandemic days, as shutdowns dragged on, odes to the lost joys of the dance floor became a motif in media. Recollections of sweaty nights out in crowded clubs captured much of what Covid had taken from us: community, freedom, gloriously messy physical proximity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: How to Plan a Veggie New Year’s Eve
description: For a small celebration, portobello au poivre is just the thing.
content: I’m at home in Los Angeles, vaccinated, boosted, happy to be alive and absolutely exhausted — frazzled and shattered in ways I didn’t even know I could be. What a year. I’m not going to a party tomorrow, but I’ll celebrate with my husband, a couple of friends, two good dogs in silly hats and a big dinner at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Jenny Gross
title: Amy Schneider Wins the Most Consecutive ‘Jeopardy!’ Games of Any Female Contestant
description: Ms. Schneider won her 21st “Jeopardy!” game in a row, bringing her total earnings to $806,000.
content: When Amy Schneider was an eighth grader in Dayton, Ohio, her fellow students voted her most likely to appear on “Jeopardy!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan, Edgar Sandoval and Mitch Smith
title: A few U.S. cities say to New Year’s revelers: Party on.
description: Most large New Year’s Eve events in the U.S. have been canceled or pared down, but Chicago, Las Vegas and San Antonio are a few of the anomalies.
content: Most large New Year’s Eve events in the United States have been canceled or diminished, as the nation shattered its record for new daily coronavirus cases on Wednesday. But Chicago, Las Vegas and San Antonio are a few of the anomalies, having neither scrapped nor pared back their plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Seal Team’ Review: Leave No Pun Behind
description: In this animated film, hotheaded seals form a squadron to defend their colony from a shiver of sharks.
content: “Seal Team,” a cartoon from Greig Cameron and Kane Croudace, is an ’80s surf shirt come to life, a neon assault of screeching metal guitars and bellowing inanity. Radical, dudes — make that pups — since the leads are hotheaded seals who form a squadron to defend their colony from a shiver of sharks. Sounds fictitious, but National Geographic once documented such a counterattack off the coast of South Africa, albeit without any shouts of “Kiss my tail fin!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Coughlin
title: The Voice Mail Message From John Madden That I’ll Never Forget
description: Madden was many things over a legendary career, but he was always a football coach first.
content: John Madden loved football. He loved the game and the competition, and he shared that passion with everyone who tuned in for the three decades he was on the air, myself included. But for all his contributions over a legendary career, John was a football coach first.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From African Art to 3,000 Years of Athens History
description: A selection of books published this week.
content: VERDE, by Federico Rios Escobar. (Raya Editorial, $41.56.) The photojournalist spent more than a decade following the guerrillas of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) through Colombian jungles, documenting their day-to-day lives, personal and political.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Ben McFall, ‘the Heart of the Strand,’ Is Dead at 73
description: He was the longest-tenured bookseller in the history of New York’s most storied bookstore, and he perpetuated its bohemian character.
content: Ben McFall, the longest-tenured bookseller in the history of the Strand, New York’s renowned bookstore, who for decades peered above his spectacles at a line of acolytes, tourists and young colleagues for whom he incarnated the store’s erudite but easygoing spirit, died on Dec. 22 at his home in Jersey City, N.J. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Vocabulary Challenge for English Learners: Write a Story Using Our Words of the Day
description: E.L.L. students are invited to write a 50-word story using our recent vocabulary words. Send us yours by Jan. 31.
content: Note: Winners of the November Vocabulary Challenge are announced at the bottom of this post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Britain plans field wards to meet the Omicron surge.
description: Unlike the “Nightingale hospitals” that went largely unused during the first virus wave, the new facilities are designed for patients needing less intensive treatment.
content: Britain’s National Health Service “is now on a war footing,” one of its top medical officials warned on Thursday, saying its hospitals would erect field wards to help absorb the impact of a record surge in coronavirus cases that has already produced a rise in hospitalizations nationally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura O'Neill, Jolie Ruben and Jessie Wender
title: Our Favorite Arts Photos of 2021
description: These are the pictures that defined an unpredictable year across the worlds of art, music, dance and performance.
content: A crush of vaccinated fans pumping their wristbanded hands in the air as rock music returned to Madison Square Garden after 460 days. A masked standing ovation as “Hadestown” became one of the first musicals back on Broadway. A sweaty, pulsing Brooklyn party — social, not distanced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and Lauren Hirsch
title: It’s another tough day for air travel, with more than 1,200 U.S. cancellations.
description: JetBlue and Alaska Airlines are among the hardest hit as weather and the latest coronavirus wave continue to snarl operations.
content: Airlines have been preparing for the holiday season for months, reviewing plans and readying reserves of workers. But that wasn’t enough to mitigate the effects of the fast-spreading Omicron coronavirus and of heavy snow and strong winds in the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Rosenbloom
title: Apps for Travelers Dreaming of Their Next Trip
description: Yes, there’s turmoil in the travel world right now, but many people are still eager to linger over plans for future journeys. These new online tools will help.
content: While travel is fraught amid the rise of the Omicron variant, people are still dreaming of their next getaway. There are even new apps to make trips easier to plan and enjoy. A number of them were introduced (and some old favorites were updated) back when travel was at a standstill. Wondering which to try? Here is a selection with thoughtful solutions — how to turn award points into a hotel suite, join a ranger for a national park hike, hear the history of the place you’re driving through, see the latest Covid-19 travel protocols — to help you tap and swipe your way to what will hopefully be a new year of adventures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: On Broadway Stages, the Beautiful Rooms Are Empty
description: In recent musicals, hyperdesign is outstripping writing and direction for clarity, expressiveness and excitement.
content: When Bobbie’s balloons are more fascinating than she is, your production of “Company” has a serious problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib
title: 16 New Books Coming in January
description: This month brings memoirs from Carl Bernstein and Bernardine Evaristo, a biography of Lorraine Hansberry, two high-octane thrillers and much more.
content: This coming-of-age debut follows David, a teenager on Florida’s Gulf Coast, as he battles drug addiction, dips in and out of jail and eventually, falls back on his love of reading to find solid ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Australia relaxes its isolation rules to adapt to Omicron.
description: To reduce labor shortages and strain on testing facilities as the Omicron variant spreads, Australia on Thursday drastically narrowed the category of people ordered to isolate after being in contact with a virus case.
content: To reduce labor shortages and strain on testing facilities as the Omicron variant spreads, Australia on Thursday drastically narrowed the category of people ordered to isolate after being in contact with a virus case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Ungerrymandered: Michigan’s Maps, Independently Drawn, Set Up Fair Fight
description: A citizen ballot initiative took redistricting out of the hands of partisan legislators. The result: competitive political districts — and an example of how to push back against hyperpartisanship.
content: One of the country’s most gerrymandered political maps has suddenly been replaced by one of the fairest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Hughes
title: A Theater Treasure of St. Marks Place Faces Closure
description: Battered by a coronavirus lockdown and conflict over a loan, Theater 80 could become another New York City casualty of the pandemic.
content: There are fewer and fewer places left in New York City where you can walk through a door and feel transported back in time. Among them is 80 St. Marks Place, a Prohibition-era speakeasy converted into an Off Broadway theater in the early 1960s.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually.
content: When plans for in-person New Year’s Eve entertainment collapse, network TV may offer as reliable a fallback as any. This year, Miley Cyrus will host NBC’s New Year’s coverage with the “Saturday Night Live” star Pete Davidson, bringing a younger, unrulier energy to a gig that has been held by Carson Daly since 2004.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: World Junior Championship, a showcase for hockey’s top prospects, is canceled.
description: The cancellation was an ominous sign for sports leagues, including the N.H.L. and the N.B.A., which have been struggling to maintain schedules.
content: The World Junior Championship, an annual showcase of the next generation of hockey stars, which was already underway in Canada, was canceled on Wednesday as the rapid spread of the Omicron variant of the coronavirus continued to wreak havoc on the sports world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: J&J’s booster shot provides strong protection against severe disease from Omicron, a study says.
description: Two shots of the vaccine reduced the risk of hospitalization from the fast-spreading variant by 85 percent, a clinical trial found.
content: A Johnson & Johnson booster shot provided strong protection against the Omicron variant, greatly reducing the risk of hospitalization, according to a clinical trial in South Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Joseph Goldstein
title: Eric Adams will keep N.Y.C.’s first-in-nation private-sector vaccine mandate in place.
description: Following weeks of silence, Mayor-elect Eric Adams vowed on Thursday to keep New York City’s vaccine mandate for private-sector employees in place. The requirement, which was enacted by Mayor Bill de Blasio and is the first of its kind in the nation, went into effect on Monday, during Mr. de Blasio’s last week in office.
content: Following weeks of silence, Mayor-elect Eric Adams vowed on Thursday to keep New York City’s vaccine mandate for private-sector employees in place. The requirement, which was enacted by Mayor Bill de Blasio and is the first of its kind in the nation, went into effect on Monday, during Mr. de Blasio’s last week in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Ghislaine Maxwell is found guilty.
content: A federal jury in Manhattan found Ghislaine Maxwell, the former companion to the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein, guilty of conspiring with him for at least a decade to recruit, groom and sexually abuse underage girls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Sarah Cahalan
title: The U.S. breaks its single-day case record, nearly doubling the highest numbers from last winter.
description: The new daily case total topped 488,000 on Wednesday, according to a New York Times database.
content: With a caseload nearly twice that of the worst single days of last winter, the United States shattered its record for new daily coronavirus cases, a milestone that may still fall short of describing the true toll of the Delta and Omicron variants because testing has slowed over the holidays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum and Farah Miller
title: How to Improve Your Mental Health in 2022
description: Well’s most popular stories of the year offered tools to stay happy and healthy.
content: The year 2021 was one of emotional whiplash. There was anticipation for vaccines, followed by confusing rollouts. Then, we saw some hope as many Americans were inoculated, only to find new variants, a tumultuous news cycle and widespread confusion around the bend. The good news is that people across the country — including experts, public figures and kids — started talking more openly and helpfully about the importance of mental health. Here at Well, we offered tools to stay balanced in the face of so much stress and anxiety. As the year comes to a close, we’ve collected the top pieces of advice from our most popular mental health stories to help you carry calm and clarity into 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: No-Sweat Answers to Some Basic Wine Questions
description: Don’t let fussy protocol interfere with the pleasure of enjoying a bottle. Best practices can help, but they should never inhibit.
content: The first and most important thing to know about drinking wine is this: There are no rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: South Africa says that it has passed its fourth wave of cases, and counts few added deaths.
description: Case counts are down by 30 percent in the last week, researchers in the country said.
content: The South African government said Thursday that data from its health department suggested that the country had passed its Omicron peak without a major spike in deaths, offering cautious hope to other countries grappling with the variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Winkie
title: One Night at Mom’s Spaghetti
description: Eminem opened a restaurant in Detroit. We checked it out.
content: DETROIT — On Sept. 27, a strange 30-second film appeared on Eminem’s YouTube channel: not a music video teaser, or the first few verses of a new rap single, but a quick-moving advertisement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: Chicken Soup for the Weary Soul
description: After another difficult year, finding joyful moments in cooking can feel impossible. But for our columnist Eric Kim, it’s a worthy resolution for the new year.
content: The very first time I boiled a whole chicken, nearly 10 years ago, I was overwhelmed by how much it perfumed my apartment with the scent of my mother’s kitchen. I wasn’t trying to recreate her samgyetang, but I did, by accident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: With Exasperation, College Football Is Just Trying to Get Through the Playoff
description: Frustrations with the pandemic in college sports have mirrored the challenges seen well beyond athletics.
content: In this malleable, ebb-and-flow pandemic world, there may be one certainty gleaned from the last nearly two years of living with the coronavirus: that here and there may not look very much alike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meredith Mendelsohn
title: Doris Lee, Unjustly Forgotten, Gets a Belated but Full Blown Tribute
description: Shining a spotlight on a painter and illustrator at the nexus of folk art and Modernism. She appeared everywhere, from W.P.A. murals to Life magazine. Then she disappeared.
content: Shipped off to boarding school as a teenager in 1920 “to get the edges polished off and prepare for college,” the artist Doris Lee cut her hair to rebel against her surroundings — “the least adventuresome and imaginative” in her life, with no access to painting. This act of rebellion was met with suspension and the school’s admonishment that “nice girls have long hair.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: Will more rapid tests change how America counts Covid cases?
description: Millions of rapid at-home Covid tests are flying off pharmacy shelves across the United States, giving Americans an instant, if sometimes imperfect, read on whether they are infected with the coronavirus.
content: Millions of rapid at-home Covid tests are flying off pharmacy shelves across the United States, giving Americans an instant, if sometimes imperfect, read on whether they are infected with the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Wright-Piersanti and Claire Moses
title: Making Sense of Covid Changes
description: What experts say about new C.D.C. rules and rising case numbers.
content: As we approach the third year of the pandemic, the coronavirus continues to make life difficult — and confusing. Official guidance on masks, testing and isolation change as new variants emerge, and a stream of case numbers turns us into armchair epidemiologists, trying to figure out how risky it is to attend a New Year’s Eve party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Manhattan D.A. Leaves Office With One Big Case Up in the Air
description: Cyrus R. Vance Jr.’s third and final term as Manhattan district attorney is ending, but his investigation into former President Donald J. Trump goes on.
content: Much of the furniture had been hauled away. The walls were stripped bare. And the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., sat on a brown leather couch in his eighth-floor office earlier this month, considering the last big question before him as his term neared its end: Would he decide whether to charge Donald J. Trump with a crime?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Años Viejos: Torching the Old Year to Toast the New One
description: In parts of Latin America, the traditional burning of rag dolls was used to symbolically banish the woes of the year gone by. Nowadays, it’s not uncommon to see TV hosts and ex-presidents going up in flames.
content: Every December, Jaime Ivan Salazar and his family, like many in Colombia, Ecuador and other parts of Latin America, construct an “año viejo”: a human-size doll stuffed with rags, newspaper or wood scraps and styled with old clothes that is burned on New Year’s Eve to symbolically cast off the old year and bring in the new.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Why the Attorney General Stalled a Move to Collect Cuomo’s Book Profits
description: A state ethics panel said the former governor had to turn over an estimated $5.1 million in proceeds. Not so fast, the attorney general responded.
content: After a succession of damaging body blows to his political career, public image and reputation, former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo seemed to finally get some good news as the end of the year approached.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Loss of Rights Group Saddens the Russians Touched by Its Work
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 30, 2021.
content: “They are trying to erase our memory. There is a feeling that they are trying to somehow paint over what happened then, so that we cannot compare it with what is happening now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel and Kellen Browning
title: The Metaverse’s Dark Side: Here Come Harassment and Assaults
description: As Meta and other companies bet big on an immersive digital world, questions about its harms are rising.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Chanelle Siggens recently strapped on an Oculus Quest virtual reality headset to play her favorite shooter game, Population One. Once she turned on the game, she maneuvered her avatar into a virtual lobby in the immersive digital world and waited for the action to begin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: N.B.A. hopefuls get their chance as a virus surge sweeps the league.
description: More than 80 players have signed 10-day contracts with N.B.A. teams this season as the  coronavirus, especially the Omicron variant, has depleted rosters across the U.S. pro basketball league. A recent decision to shorten required isolation time for some infected players could help teams get their usual stars back sooner.
content: More than 80 players have signed 10-day contracts with N.B.A. teams this season as the  coronavirus, especially the Omicron variant, has depleted rosters across the U.S. pro basketball league. A recent decision to shorten required isolation time for some infected players could help teams get their usual stars back sooner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Azari
title: A.O.C. and Manchin Are in the Same Party. No Wonder Democrats Are Struggling.
description: The party has always struggled to figure out how to represent a diverse group of voters with different interests and goals.
content: The promise of Joe Biden’s candidacy for president was his potential to assemble a coalition of progressives, liberal and moderate Democrats, and even disaffected conservatives looking for an alternative to Donald Trump. In 2020, this meant that Mr. Biden won a solid, but not landslide, victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: What to Know About the Times Square Ball Drop on New Year’s Eve
description: The longstanding tradition will return to Times Square this year, with some safety measures in place, as Covid-19 surges. Here’s how to watch.
content: As New Yorkers get ready to kick the door closed on 2021, crowds will return to Times Square on Friday for the annual ball drop — despite the surge in Covid-19 cases in New York City and across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Whether you’re trying to squeeze one last book into 2021 or making your reading plans for the new year, here are eight options: four fiction and four nonfiction. In just those few nonfiction books, you have a choice from a wide range of subject matter. “Flying Blind” investigates two airplane crashes; the illustrator Edward Sorel, now 92, writes about his life and career; Claude A. Clegg III examines what the Obama presidency meant to Black Americans; and Rob Dunn argues that we need (urgently) to understand our position in relation to nature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel approves a 4th dose of Covid vaccine for those with compromised immune systems.
description: The Ministry of Health said it was waiting for more data from Israel and abroad before approving any broader rollout of fourth shots.
content: JERUSALEM — Israel on Thursday approved a fourth dose of Covid vaccine for people with weakened immune systems, moving ahead of much of the world in taking a little-studied step to try to protect its most vulnerable against the fast-spreading Omicron variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Snyder
title: Is the Human Impulse to Tell Stories Dangerous?
description: In “The Story Paradox,” Jonathan Gottschall explores how narrative shapes reality and our own actions.
content: THE STORY PARADOXHow Our Love of Storytelling Builds Societies and Tears Them DownBy Jonathan Gottschall
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Year 3
description: Times reporters tell us what pandemic developments they’re watching.
content: As we prepare to enter the third year of the pandemic, we have been hoping for more normality and less Covid disruption by now. Case counts are soaring to all-time highs in some parts of the world, and 2022 is shaping up to be just as uncertain as the last 12 months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Dana Rubinstein
title: Beleaguered by Omicron, New York Operates at Half Speed
description: From subway lines to medical clinics to libraries, city businesses and services have been curtailed because of Covid.
content: On the day that New York City set a one-day coronavirus case record for the third time in a week, an entire subway line that connects Queens to Manhattan was closed because so many transit workers had fallen ill. Other lines faced delays.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Grand Jury Report in Anthony Ardo Case
description: In a public report, the grand jury raised questions about how the state police had investigated Trooper Jay Splain’s shooting of Mr. Ardo, calling the agency “arrogant.”
content: In a public report, the grand jury raised questions about how the state police had investigated Trooper Jay Splain’s shooting of Mr. Ardo, calling the agency “arrogant.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Drive My Car’ and More
description: I’m The Times’s classical music and dance reporter. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.
content: I’m The Times’s classical music and dance reporter. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Ellis
title: Sports Stories That Hit Home in 2021
description: Take a look at some of The Times’s most-read sports coverage of the year.
content: Take a look at some of The Times’s most-read sports coverage of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Candace Jackson
title: Two Children, One Bathroom: A Los Angeles Family Stretches the Budget for an Upgrade. Which Home Would You Choose?
description: Finding a house big enough to accommodate their growing family was hard enough. Doing it just as the pandemic market exploded was even trickier.
content: Finding a house big enough to accommodate their growing family was hard enough. Doing it just as the pandemic market exploded was even trickier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Toby Bilanow
title: Weekly Health Quiz: New Year’s Parties, Heart Health and a Common Eye Problem
description: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
source.name: The New York Times

title: District Attorney Press Release on Charity Thome Shooting
description: Lebanon County District Attorney Pier Hess Graf said the shooting of Ms. Thome by Trooper Jay Splain and a rookie trooper was justified. She also said officers feared that Ms. Thome’s vehicle posed a danger to them or to other officers.
content: Lebanon County District Attorney Pier Hess Graf said the shooting of Ms. Thome by Trooper Jay Splain and a rookie trooper was justified. She also said officers feared that Ms. Thome’s vehicle posed a danger to them or to other officers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Filing by Anthony Ardo’s Family
description: In opposing the state police’s motion for summary judgment, Mr. Ardo’s parents’ lawyers questioned why officers did not try to de-escalate their confrontation with Mr. Ardo, who had repeatedly threatened to kill himself.
content: In opposing the state police’s motion for summary judgment, Mr. Ardo’s parents’ lawyers questioned why officers did not try to de-escalate their confrontation with Mr. Ardo, who had repeatedly threatened to kill himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lazaro Gamio, Albert Sun and Alexandria Symonds
title: See Where Virus Cases Are Rising Fastest as Global Count Tops One Million Per Day
description: Steep surges driven by the Omicron variant have led to record-breaking rates of new cases in the United States, Canada, Australia and across Western Europe.
content: Steep surges driven by the Omicron variant have led to record-breaking rates of new cases in the United States, Canada, Australia and across Western Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Caseloads Spike as Omicron Spreads
description: The latest news and data from the team tracking the coronavirus.
content: The latest news and data from the team tracking the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Bergeron
title: John Madden Changed How We Consume Football
description: His excitable and affable personality, and innovations from broadcasting to video games, made him the embodiment of America’s new national pastime.
content: His excitable and affable personality, and innovations from broadcasting to video games, made him the embodiment of America’s new national pastime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Valentino-DeVries
title: What I Saw While Covering In-Custody Deaths
description: My colleagues and I have been investigating experts who help exonerate police officers after deaths in custody.
content: My colleagues and I have been investigating experts who help exonerate police officers after deaths in custody.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Charity Thome Lawsuit
description: Lawyers say that the shooting of Ms. Thome by Trooper Jay Splain and a rookie trooper was unjustified and that she didn’t pose a danger to anyone when they fired at her vehicle.
content: Lawyers say that the shooting of Ms. Thome by Trooper Jay Splain and a rookie trooper was unjustified and that she didn’t pose a danger to anyone when they fired at her vehicle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gonzalez
title: Why We Dance in the Streets of New York
description: For many Puerto Rican New Yorkers, dance is an expression of joy, protest and prayer.
content: For many Puerto Rican New Yorkers, dance is an expression of joy, protest and prayer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This week’s homes are in Lenox Hill, Chelsea and Flatbush.
content: This week’s homes are in Lenox Hill, Chelsea and Flatbush.
source.name: The New York Times

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Warren, N.J.
content: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Warren, N.J.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. Attorney Damian Williams Responds to Maxwell Guilty Verdict
description: In a video statement, Damian Williams, the U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York, commended Maxwell’s accusers for their bravery and courage.
content: In a video statement, Damian Williams, the U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York, commended Maxwell’s accusers for their bravery and courage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 30, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Dec. 30, 2021.
content: An article on Tuesday about Saudi Arabia’s efforts to become a cultural capital described imprecisely the size of its population. Saudi Arabia’s population is about 35 million, not 22 million, which refers only to its citizens.
source.name: The New York Times
